episodes.title: Tripmaster Monkey: His Fake Book
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: This podcast, taken from the ALOUD archive, is a discussion from 1998's \"Racing Towards the Millenium: Voices From the American West,\" a predecessor to ALOUD.

episodes.title: Are You Somebody?
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A novel about of a woman who refused to shrink from a life alone, and who comes to terms with the love she learns to share with both men and women.

episodes.title: John Updike, LAPL Literary Awards 1999
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The great American writer John Updike received the Los Angeles Public Library's Literary Award in 1999. The award, given annually, is granted to a writer for his or her contribution to literature. Updike joins past winners Norman Mailer, Harper Lee, Susan Sontag, and Seamus Heaney in receiving this honor. The following recording is taken from his acceptance speech at the Library Foundation of Los Angeles' Annual Awards dinner.

episodes.title: Why Choose to Love?
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: This podcast, taken from the ALOUD archive, is a discussion from 1999's \"The Big Questions\" series.  A celebration of writing, reading, and public debate, \"The Big Questions\" features visionary thinkers in the arts, sciences, and humanities who are asking new questions, challenging accepted theories, and reframing ancient dialects.

episodes.title: Robert Pinsky: What Shall We Teach the Young?
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Robert Pinsky answers the question, "What Shall We Teach the Young?", touching on art and poetry.This program was presented by ALOUD's The Big Questions Series.

episodes.title: Poetry Reading
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: This podcast, taken from the ALOUD archive, is a discussion from 2000's \"Words In the World\" series; a curated series of artists whose stories, essays, poems, novels, and films illuminated a global culture in crisis and celebration, extending their imaginations into the vast territory of the heart and the world.

episodes.title: War in a Time of Peace: Bush, Clinton, and the Generals
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: An in-depth look at the impact of Vietnam on post-Cold War U.S. foreign policy by a distinguished Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist.

episodes.title: A Human Being Died That Night: A South African Story of Forgiveness
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A psychologist on South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission asks, "What does it mean when we discover than the incarnation of evil is as frighteningly human as we are?" In Conversation with Louise Steinman

episodes.title: The Sorrows of Empire: Militarism, Secrecy and the End of the Republic
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The author of the prophetic national bestseller \"Blowback,\" offers a vivid look at the new caste of professional warriors who have infiltrated multiple branches of government, for whom the manipulation of the military budget is of vital interest. In conversation with journalist WARREN OLNEY (\"To the Point\").

episodes.title: An evening with poet W.S.Merwin
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In a career spanning five decades, W.S. Merwin, lauded poet, translator, and environmental activist, has become one of the most widely read poets in America.

episodes.title: The Mysterious Flame of Queen Loana
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: While he can remember the plot of every book he's ever read, the hero of Eco's raucous new novel no longer knows his own name.

episodes.title: Jane Smiley: Thirteen Ways of Looking at the Novel
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Two great writers celebrate the novel—from the 1,000 year-old Tale of Genji to Zadie Smith’s recent bestseller White Teeth; from classics to little-known gems.This program was presented by ALOUD.

episodes.title: Fledgling
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Butler, one of the world's great science fiction writers, explores the limits of  "otherness" in her new novel-the story of a young, amnesiac girl whose alarmingly unhuman needs and abilities lead her to a startling conclusion.

episodes.title: George Packer: The Assassins’ Gate: America in Iraq
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Packer, award-winning staff writer for The New Yorker, explores the full range of ideas and emotions stirred up by our most controversial foreign-policy venture since Vietnam.This program was presented by ALOUD in 2005, and the recording from our archive was added into our podcast collection in 2014.

episodes.title: Armistead Maupin: A Night Listener
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Armistead Maupin discusses his book, A Night Listener.This program was presented by the  Hot Off the Press series.

episodes.title: Reza Aslan: The Coming Reformation of Islam: A Conversation
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Join two brilliant scholars of religion for a fascinating discussion on the internal conflict within Islam over the scope and outcome of the Islamic Reformation.This program was presented by ALOUD in 2006, and the recording from our archive was added to our podcast collection in 2014.

episodes.title: Geraldine Brooks: March: A Novel
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Geraldine Brooks - in conversation with Carla Kaplan, Professor of English, USC - is the author of a luminous second novel (after 2001’s acclaimed Year of Wonders) entitled March: A Novel. This book imagines the Civil War experiences of Mr. March, the absent father in Louisa May Alcott’s Little Women.This program was presented by ALOUD.

episodes.title: Tête-à-Tête: Simone de Beauvoir and Jean-Paul Sartre
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Rowley, a distinguished biographer and Obst, legendary producer of films such as "Sleepless in Seattle" offers an intimate look at one of the world's most unconventional love stories.

episodes.title: Michael Pollan: In Defense of Food
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The author of the national bestseller The Omnivore's Dilemma returns with a manifesto for our times: what to eat, what not to eat, and how to think about health.This program was presented by ALOUD.

episodes.title: Life as Art, Art as Life
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Pekar, known for his autobiographical slice-of-life comic book series \"American Splendor\" and author of the just-released Ego & Hubris: The Michael Malice Story discusses artistic strategies and kvetching as a form of \"Outsider Realism\" with Conal, L.A.'s own iconic anti-icon master and guerrilla poster artist.

episodes.title: The Battle Over Books: Authors & Publishers Take on the Google Books Library Project
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A provocative discussion about the competing interests and issues raised by The Google Books Library Project, and whether a universal digital repository of our collective knowledge is in our future. With: Allan Adler, Association of American Publishers; David Drummond, Google; Fontayne Holmes, Los Angeles Public Library; Jonathan Kirsch, author and lawyer, Lawrence Lessig, Stanford Law School, and Gary Wolf, WIRED Magazine.

episodes.title: A Writer's Life
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Gordon, one of America's master story-tellers, probes the lives of her characters and how the workings of the world- both enormous events and intimate moments-define and change us. She discusses her writing life on the publication of the complete collection of her remarkable short fictions.

episodes.title: The Light of Evening: A Novel
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The great Irish novelist--known as a pioneer for her frank portrayals of women--discusses her daring new work that explores the unbreakable bond between mother and child. \"O'Brien is a storyteller, an Irish story-teller, one of an ancient tradition of storytellers, people who tell the truth.\" (Thomas Cahill, Los Angeles Times Book Review)

episodes.title: Deadwood: Stories of the Black Hills
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The creator/executive producer and cast members of HBO's \"Deadwood\" discuss the themes and motivations that run through the series - gold, Custer, betrayal, profanity - and the remarkable accidents of history that created the wildest town in the West.

episodes.title: Point to Point Navigation: A Memoir
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The inimitable raconteur, essayist, novelist, playwright, historian, critic and screenwriter travels in memory through the arenas of literature, television, film, theater, politics, and international society.

episodes.title: Dancing in the Streets: A History of Collective Joy
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: What are the deep origins of communal celebration in human biology and culture? Join us for an original and exhilarating look at one of humanity's oldest traditions.

episodes.title: House of Meetings
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A surprising love story set in 1946 Moscow and a camp in the Arctic Circle by the bestselling author of London Fields.

episodes.title: Can Religion and Reason be Reconciled?
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Aslan (No god but God: The Origins, Evolution, and Future of Islam) and Harris (The End of Faith: Religion, Terror, and the Future of Reason; Letter to a Christian Nation) square off for the first time to debate the future of religion and its role in society.

episodes.title: Power, Faith and Fantasy: America in the Middle East 1776 to the Present
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Oren, recently visiting professor at Harvard and Yale and author of the best-selling Six Days of War - covers 230 years of America's political, military, and intellectual involvement in the Middle East from George Washington to George W. Bush.

episodes.title: A Field Guide to Getting Lost
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Solnit-activist and cultural historian-draws on emblematic moments of uncertainty, trust, loss, memory, desire and place in brilliant autobiographical essays exploring how we find ourselves or lose ourselves.

episodes.title: Between the Sheets: Sex, Literature, and the Future of Erotic Fiction
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In a society in which sex is both a major obsession and a major taboo, what is the function of erotic literature? Is there a new receptivity to thinking and writing about the sexual dimension? Join two award-winning American writers for a provocative discussion.

episodes.title: Debating Race
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Whether chronicling the class conflict in the African American community or exposing the failings of the government response to Hurricane Katrina, Dyson never shies away from controversy. Join two of America's most astute intellectuals in a discussion about issues that matter.

episodes.title: A Long Way Gone: Memoirs of a Boy Solider
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: At age twelve, Beah (now twenty-five), fled attacking rebels in his native Sierra Leone and was picked up by the government army. What is war like through the eyes of a child soldier? How does one become a killer? How does one stop?

episodes.title: Nathan Englander: The Ministry of Special Cases
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: From the celebrated author of “For the Relief of Unbearable Urges”, a stunning historical novel—his first—set in Buenos Aires at the start of Argentina’s Dirty War. This program was presented by ALOUD.

episodes.title: Telling Stories that Matter: A Conversation
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Two California-born writers-one from East L.A. and the other from the Central Valley-discuss their understanding of stories as a way to complicate our views of self, of morality, and of our relationships with the world around us.

episodes.title: The Pest House
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: On a devastated, lawless American continent, families have only one hope: passage on a ship to Europe. A remarkable novel by one of the most inventive novelists writing in English today.

episodes.title: God is Not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: \"America's foremost literary pugilist\" (Village Voice) offers an elegantly argued case against all religions.

episodes.title: Parts Per Million: The Poisoning of Beverly Hills High School
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: An unsettling and timely investigation into the ties between Beverly Hills, its oil wells, and a local cancer cluster. A compelling legal drama by a journalist and member of the Beverly Hills High School class of '71.

episodes.title: An Evening with Graphic Designer Chip Kidd
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Kidd’s book jacket designs for Alfred A. Knopf (where he has worked since 1986) have helped spawn a revolution in the art of American book packaging. “The history of book design can be split into two eras: before graphic designer Chip Kidd and after.” (Time Out New York) Presented on the occasion of the exhibition “Dancing by the Light of the Moon: The Art of Fred Marcellino” in Central Library’s Getty Gallery.

episodes.title: Nell Freudenberger and Jennifer Gilmore
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Gilmore's Golden Country vividly brings to life the intertwining stories of three immigrants seeking their fortunes. In Freudenberger's The Dissident, a performance artist/political activist collides with a wealthy Beverly Hills family. In these extraordinary first novels, family dynamics and cultures in collision are limned with hilarity and wisdom.

episodes.title: The Book of Psalms: A Conversation
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Robert Alter's translation of \"The Five Books of Moses\" was hailed as a \"godsend\" by poet Seamus Heaney. He discusses with Kirsch, also a Biblical scholar, his new translation of the timeless Book of Psalms.

episodes.title: Two Actors, Two Authors, Two Lives
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Alda and Farrell, former co-stars of M*A*S*H, both authors of recent memoirs, re-unite to discuss art, activism, family, money, and fame.

episodes.title: COOL IT: The Skeptical Environmentalist's Guide to Global Warming
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A highly respected statistical analyst of climate discusses why and how he believes the debate over climate change, fueled by politicians and the media, has stifled rational dialogue and marginalized meaningful dissent.

episodes.title: No Simple Victory: Europe at War 1939-1945
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: One of the world's preeminent scholars of World War II history, author of the bestselling Europe: A History and Rising '44, offers a clear-eyed reappraisal and an illuminating portrait of a conflict that continues to provoke debate today.

episodes.title: The Terror Dream: Fear and Fantasy in Post-9/11 America
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The Pulitzer Prize- winning author of Stiffed and Backlash examines the post-9/11 outpouring in the media, popular culture, and political life and offers a fiercely original view of ourselves, our history, and the future we may unwittingly be creating.

episodes.title: The American Idea
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: For 150 years, The Atlantic Monthly has explored what its founders-including Emerson, Longfellow and Holmes-called \"The American Idea.\" Join us for a high-spirited discussion with celebrated Atlantic contributors about the role literary masters have played in interpreting and often rebuking American society and culture.

episodes.title: Hotel de Dream: A New York Novel
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The acclaimed memoirist, author, and biographer of Jean Genet conjures the true-life love affair between author Stephen Crane and the woman known as his wife.

episodes.title: Musicophilia: Tales of Music and the Brain
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: \"The poet laureate of medicine\" (New York Times) examines the complexities of our response to music and the particular powers of music to move us physically and emotionally, beneficially or destructively, showing how we humans are a musical species no less than a linguistic one.

episodes.title: The Rest is Noise: Listening to the Twentieth Century
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The New Yorker's brilliant music critic takes us inside the labyrinth of modern sound, from Vienna before World War I to New York City in the seventies. Through experiments, revolutions, riots, and friendships forged and broken-come listen to a history of the twentieth century through its music.

episodes.title: The Conscience of a Liberal
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Today's most widely read economist weaves together a nuanced account of three generations of history with sharp political, social, and economic analysis.

episodes.title: The Principles of Uncertainty: Illustrations, Parables, Films
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The illustrator, author and designer-known for her many New Yorker covers (including the famous map of \"Newyorkistan\")-contends with existential questions like: \"What is identity?\" \"Why do we fight wars?\" \"Why do hearts break in February and why do some people have a hankering for a dodo sandwich?\"  Note: you are encouraged to wear your favorite hat to this program.

episodes.title: Psychogeography: Disentangling the Modern Conundrum of Psyche and Place
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Evoking places as far flung as Iowa and India, Self-cultural provocateur, writer and long distance walker-teamed with legendary Gonzo illustrator Ralph Steadman to explore the intimate effects of geographical environment on human emotion and behavior.

episodes.title: A Life Decoded
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A riveting account of the unparalleled drama of the quest for the human genome by the scientist who went on to be the first to read and interpret his own genome.

episodes.title: Mongrels, Bastards, Orphans & Vagabonds: Mexican Immigration and the Future of Race in America
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The iconoclastic Los Angeles Times columnist discusses how the mestizo legacy of Mexican-Americans, the largest immigrant group in the country's history, will forever change how Americans think about race and ethnicity.

episodes.title: A Free Life
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In this new novel by the National Book Award-winning author of Waiting, an Ã©migrÃ© Chinese writer opens a restaurant in Atlanta in a daunting attempt to find his voice as a poet, support his family, and realize the American Dream.

episodes.title: An Evening with Poet Galway Kinnell
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In the 2003 National Book Award judges' citation for his New Selected Poems, Kinnell was called \"America's preeminent visionary,\" with work in 12 collections that, \"greets each new age with rapture and abundance ... [and] sets him at the table with his mentors: Rilke, Whitman and Frost.\"

episodes.title: Memorial Reading for Mutanabbi Street
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: On March 5, 2007, a car bomb exploded on Mutanabbi Street, the lively center of Baghdad bookselling, filled with bookstores, cafes, and book stalls. 30 people were killed; more than 100 were wounded. Join poets and writers to memorialize this wounding of Baghdad's literary and intellectual heart.

episodes.title: Theories of Everything
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The New Yorker cartoonist who can explain phenomena such as \"The Museum of One's Kitchen\" (including the Refrigerator Door Gallery and the Cabinet of Many Teas) recently collaborated with Steve Martin on The Alphabet from A to Y With Bonus Letter Z.

episodes.title: Lost and Found: Writing in the Woods
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary:
Two writers discuss their experiences writing at the historic MacDowell Colony then read from work begun or completed there.

www.macdowellcolony.org

episodes.title: Cleopatra's Nose: 39 Varieties of Desire
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The longtime New Yorker writer--who once spent an evening with Jackie Onassis, smoking cigarettes and talking about men--culls from 20 years of probing and delightful cultural critiques of fashion, its personages, trends and history, to celebrate the lasting significance of its ephemeral qualities.

episodes.title: An Evening with Poet Robert Hass
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Known also as an essayist, translator, and activist on behalf of poetry, literacy, and the environment, the former United States Poet Laureate (1995-1997) is a poet of great eloquence, clarity, and force. About Hass's work, poet Stanley Kunitz wrote, \"Reading a poem by Robert Hass is like stepping into the ocean when the temperature of the water is not much different from that of the air. You scarcely know, until you feel the undertow tug at you, that you have entered into another element.\"

episodes.title: Ending Slavery: How We Free Today's Slaves
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Slaves harvest cocoa in Ivory Coast, make charcoal used to produce steel in Brazil, weave carpets in India. The list goes on. Bales recounts his 15-year journey in search of real world solutions to ending slavery. Bales will introduce special guest Maria Suarez, an immigrant victim of sex trafficking.

episodes.title: The Long Embrace: Raymond Chandler and the Woman He Loved
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In her unconventional biography, Freeman illuminates the psyche and mystery of Chandler and his relationship with his much older wife as well as the City of Angels, to which Chandler's work is forever wed.

episodes.title: Creating a World without Poverty
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: What if you could harness the power of the free market to solve the problems of poverty, hunger, and inequality? To some, it sounds impossible. But the Nobel Peace Prizewinner who invented micro-credit is doing exactly that. Yunus's \"Next Big Idea\" offers a pioneering model for nothing less than a new, more humane form of capitalism.

episodes.title: Comeback: Conservatism That Can Win Again
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Frum-former speechwriter for President Bush-argues that Republicans, like the Democrats before them, have been the victims of their own success. He outlines a fresh vision of a GOP that can rebuild the conservative majority and elect the next Republican president.

episodes.title: Sellout: The Politics of Racial Betrayal
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In his explosive new book, Kennedy--a Harvard law scholar--shows how current fears of \"selling out\" are expressed in thought and practice and clarifies the effect they have on individuals and on American society as a whole.

episodes.title: The Height of Ambition: New Development Downtown
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Key voices in the development of downtown Los Angeles discuss their visions for the future.

episodes.title: The Science of Leonardo: Inside the Mind of the Great Genius of the Renaissance
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Drawing on more than 6,000 pages of Leonardo's surviving notebooks, Capra reveals Leonardo-whose studies ranged from the flight patterns of birds to the mechanics of light-as the unacknowledged \"father of science.\"

episodes.title: A Force of Nature: The Frontier Genius of Ernest Rutherford
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The award-winning historian offers a new intellectual biography of the twentieth century's greatest experimental physicist, whose revolutionary discoveries included the orbital structure of the atom.

episodes.title: Swimming in a Sea of Death: A Son's Memoir
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The author's mother, Susan Sontag, died of a particularly acute form of leukemia in 2004. \"This,\" he writes, \"is a book of questions about what we know and, perhaps more importantly, what we can take in when confronted by the death of a loved one.\"

episodes.title: The Commoner: A Novel
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The author of Reservation Road sets his mesmerizing new novel in 1959 Japan when Haruko, a non-aristocratic woman, marries the Crown Prince and enters the sealed-off and mysterious Japanese monarchy.

episodes.title: In Defense of Food
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The author of the national bestseller The Omnivore's Dilemma returns with a manifesto for our times: what to eat, what not to eat, and how to think about health.

episodes.title: The Flowers: A Novel
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: From one of this country's most original voices comes a masterful new novel about a young Mexican-American who falls in love while sweeping the decks of an apartment building named The Flowers. In the midst of exploding racial violence, he must decide what he values and what he can do about it.

episodes.title: When the Personal Becomes Political
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The acclaimed poet and columnist for The Nation discusses her new book of essays dealing with sex, death, ex-lovers, politics, motherhood, aging, and learning to drive.

episodes.title: Basic Brown: My Life and Our Times
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The two-term mayor of San Francisco and longest-serving speaker of the California Assembly lays down some candid rules about surviving and manipulating Big Money and Big Media in today's politics.

episodes.title: The Age of American Unreason
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: From the author of Freethinkers, a dazzlingly insightful-and occasionally hilarious-analysis of the anti-rationalism, anti-intellectualism, and anti-scientism that increasingly characterizes the cultural and intellectual life of this country.

episodes.title: Chasing the Flame: Sergio Vieira de Mello and the Fight to Save the World
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author reveals the powerful legacy of the incomparable humanitarian who lost his life in a terrorist attack on UN Headquarters in Iraq in 2003.

episodes.title: The Dancer and the Thief (El Baile de la Victoria)
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The prize-winning novelist (Il Postino)-for whom "neither life nor literature outside politics" is imaginable-sets his exuberant love story against the backdrop of the new Chile, free from the Pinochet dictatorship but prey to the perils of globalization.

episodes.title: The Enigma of Iran (or Why American Policy-makers Should Read More Fiction)
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Iran, as any civilization, is defined most thoroughly by the stories it spawns.  Join us for a candid conversation between novelist Gina Nahai (Caspian Rain) and Robert Scheer (editor-in-chief, Truthdig.com and host of KCRW's Left, Right and Center) about faith, modernism, and the emotional ties that bind the people of Iran and America.

episodes.title: The Unheard: A Memoir of Deafness and Africa
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Seeking a place where his deafness would be irrelevant, Josh Swiller volunteered for the Peace Corps and spent two years in a remote and impoverished village in Zambia. His hilarious and harrowing memoir recounts what he found there.

episodes.title: Dreams and Shadows: The Future of the Middle East
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Drawing on 35 years of reporting-through wars, revolutions and uprisings-one of America's most prescient journalists offers an insightful reckoning of the changes wracking the Middle East and their impact on its and America's future.

episodes.title: The Senator's Wife
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In her new novel, the author of the now classic The Good Mother and While I Was Gone brings emotional power to her most transfixing themes: the meaning of loyalty, history, forgiveness and grace.

episodes.title: The Ten-Cent Plague: The Great Comic-Book Scare and How It
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In the years between World War II and the emergence of television as a mass medium, American popular culture was first created in the pulpy, boldly illustrated pages of comic books. Join us for a discussion of the lost world of comic books, their creativity, irreverence, and suspicion of authority.

episodes.title: Lush Life: A Novel
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: From a great American realist-the author of Clockers and co-writer of The Wire-an X-ray of the streets of New York City in the age of no \"broken windows\" and \"quality of life\" police squads.

episodes.title: The Golden Road: Notes on My Gentrification
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Millner, a young African-American woman, grew up in predominantly Hispanic and working class San Jose and went on to Harvard. In her memoir she tours the landscapes of possibility carved by race, class and culture for young Americans.

episodes.title: The Life of the Skies: Birding at the End of Nature
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Rosen, novelist and New York Times contributor, sets out to explore birdwatching's centrality--historical and literary, spiritual and scientific--to a culture torn between the desire both to conquer and to conserve.

episodes.title: Common Wealth: Economics for a Crowded Planet
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: From the author of the bestseller The End of Poverty, a vivid map of the road to sustainable and equitable global prosperity and an augury of the global economic collapse that lies ahead if we don't follow it.

episodes.title: BONK: The Curious Coupling of Science and Sex
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Few things are as fundamental to human happiness as satisfying sex. America's funniest science writer (Stiff) offers an ode to a fascinating and vital pursuit and a reminder that there is still much to learn.

episodes.title: The Bin Ladens: An Arabian Family in the American Century
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The two-time Pulitzer Prize winner and author of the bestseller Ghost Wars presents the story of the Bin Laden family's rise to power and privilege, revealing how American influences changed the family and how one member's rebellion changed America.

episodes.title: Our Story Begins
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: One of America's \"most exquisite storytellers\" (Esquire), a master of the memoir and the short story, reads from and discusses his first collection in over a decade.

episodes.title: An Afternoon with Larry McMurtry
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Larry McMurtry-Pulitzer prize-winning novelist, Academy Award-winning, screenwriter, essayist, and bookseller-will receive the 2008 Los Angeles Public Library Literary Award on April 30. As part of the tradition of the Literary Award, the recipient delivers a free public lecture. Join Mr. McMurtry for an afternoon of insights into his work and his life. \"No other author has so thoroughly and delightfully debunked the ill-advised romanticism of the American West. An American landmark in the world of fiction.\" (Jami Edwards, on Bookreporter.com).

episodes.title: Bowl of Cherries
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: McSweeney's, publisher of the young and hip, brings us a debut novel of breadth, glee and sharp consequence by a 90-year-old ex-Marine who is also a two-time screenwriting Oscar nominee (\"Bad Day at Black Rock\") and co-creator of Mr. Magoo.

episodes.title: Notes on a Life
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Coppola-award-winning documentary filmmaker, artist, wife and mother-employs the same insight and wit as she used in her Notes on the Making of Apocalypse Now to this account of the next chapters in her life.

episodes.title: The Open Road: The Global Journey of the Fourteenth Dalai Lama
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Drawn from a three-decades-long conversation with the Dalai Lama, Iyer's book explores the hidden life, the singular thinking, and the daily challenges of a global icon.

episodes.title: The Downhill Lie: A Hacker's Return to a Ruinous Sport
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: After a 32-year absence, the bestselling author and popular Miami Herald columnist returns to the fairways-with hilarious consequences.

episodes.title: The Post-American World
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: \"This is not a book about the decline of America, but rather about the rise of everyone else,\" begins the new work by Zakaria, editor of Newsweek International and one of our most distinguished thinkers.

episodes.title: ALOUD Science Series: On Seeing and Being - "What Do You See?"
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: How do our brains construct a world from a confounding and often conflicting mass of visual cues? According to Koch, professor of Cognitive and Behavioral Biology at Caltech, understanding how we see helps us understand how we arrive at a sense of a conscious "self."This series made possible by a generous contribution from K&L Gates.

episodes.title: The Story of a Marriage
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Greer (The Confessions of Max Tivoli) looks at the climate of repression in 1950s America and asks how far we are willing to go to escape that which confines us.

episodes.title: The Bishop's Daughter
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: An acclaimed poet offers an unsparing portrait of her father-a civil rights leader and Episcopalian bishop of New York City- that explores the consequences of sexual secrets on one American family.

episodes.title: The Garden of Last Days
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The author of House of Sand and Fog offers a new novel that explores sex and parenthood, honor and masculinity.

episodes.title: Relentless Pursuit: A Year in the Trenches with Teach for America
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A candid account of a year in the life of four TFA recruits at Locke High School in South Central L.A. as they attempt to fulfill their mission to overcome the inequities in our educational system.

episodes.title: All You Can Eat: Panel Discussion
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Rising concerns over food safety and the environmental impact of industrialized agriculture suggest that the true costs of \"cheap\" calories are unsustainably high. As our food economy fast approaches its limits, California's innovative food community offers hope and a salad bar full of possible solutions.

episodes.title: Soldiers of Reason: The RAND Corporation and the Rise of the American Empire
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A page-turning chronicle of the rise of the secretive think tank--born in the wake of World War II--that has been the driving force behind American government for the last half-century.

episodes.title: The Pornography of Power: How Defense Hawks Hijacked 9/11 and weakened America
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: One of America's most admired journalists offers a manifesto for enlightened reform of the nation's military-industrial complex.

episodes.title: ALOUD Science Series: On Seeing and Being - The Body Has a Mind of Its Own
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: How does your mind know where your body ends and the outside world begins? Two acclaimed science writers discuss the largely unconscious ways that your brain builds maps of your body parts, your movements, the space around your body, the actions of others, and the sensations that lead to human emotions, health and disease.Made possible by a generous contribution from K&L Gates

episodes.title: Undiscovered
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: First time author and three-time Oscar nominated actress (An Officer and a Gentleman, Terms of Endearment, and Shadowlands), Winger reflects upon her pursuit of a life beyond acting, converting her star status into a life filled with meaning.

episodes.title: Mustang: The Saga of the Wild Horse in the American West
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The politically charged story of the wild horse in the American West, from its origins in North America to its life today, as government and lone operators with automatic weapons seek to clear it from the range.

episodes.title: Newer Poets XIII
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: This annual poetry reading for local voices introduces a cross-section of lively, talented writers who are making an impression in the Los Angeles poetry community.

episodes.title: Art and Upheaval: Artists on the World's Frontlines
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A long-time community arts advocate recounts the efforts of artists world-wide (from Soweto to Belgrade to Watts) to resolve conflict, heal unspeakable trauma, give voice to the forgotten and disappeared, and re-stitch the cultural fabric of their communities.

episodes.title: My Name is Will
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Bardologists will love this wildly imaginative farce- think \"Shakespeare in Love\" on magic mushrooms-by the co-founder of The Reduced Shakespeare Company.

episodes.title: Kafka Comes to America: Fighting for Justice in the War on Terror . . . A Public Defender's Inside Account
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: An account of the legal struggles of two men whose civil liberties were compromised as a result of the US government's counterterrorism measures employed post-9/11 and how their experiences affect us all.

episodes.title: The Black Hole War: My Battle with Stephen Hawking to Make the World Safe for Quantum Mechanics
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The inside account-with a wild cast of characters- of the battle over the true nature of black holes with nothing less than our understanding of the entire universe at stake.

episodes.title: Photographer on the Battlefield: A Photo Lecture
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary:
Please note, this program was presented in conjunction with a photo slide show.  The slide show portion of the discussion is not included in this podcast.

The longtime photojournalist for the L.A. Times, who has traveled the world documenting conflict, discusses his war photography in Iraq and Afghanistan as well as work on the project \"Altered Oceans,\" for which he shared the 2007 Pulitzer Prize.

episodes.title: Marinating in Ghetto Air: Writing and Transformation at Homeboy Industries
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Featuring readings by Homeboy poets, on the deep impact creative writing can have on liberating formerly involved gang members.

episodes.title: RADIO ALOUD: A Library of the Airwaves
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary:
This pilot radio program (never broadcast) is comprised of excerpts from three ALOUD programs:  a December 13, 2005 conversation between \"Six Feet Under\" writer/producer Alan Ball and writer/funeral director Thomas Lynch; a public talk on April 2, 2003 by playwright August Wilson, recipient of the 2003 Los Angeles Public Library Literary Award; and an April 4, 2005 poetry reading by W.S. Merwin.

Guest Host: Alfred Molina.  

Co-produced by Louise Steinman and Johanna Cooper

episodes.title: Los Angeles Without the Los Angeles Times?
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A Community Forum & Panel Discussion

episodes.title: Obscene in the Extreme: the Burning and Banning of John Steinbeck's "The Grapes of Wrath"
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Coinciding with Banned Books Week is the revelatory story behind the 1939 burning and banning of Steinbeck's book in Kern County, Calif., home of the fictional Joads.

episodes.title: Violence
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A philosopher and cultural critic-whose thought challenges traditional trajectories- takes on the signal issue of violence and inverts our pre-conceived and popular notions about its causes.

episodes.title: The Anglo Files: A Field Guide to the British
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A reporter in the New York Times London bureau offers a hilarious and incisive look at her adopted home. \"Lyall will now be hailed as one of England's supreme analysts, preparatory to her being executed on Tower Green.\" (Clive James)

episodes.title: Crime: A Novel
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Detective Inspector Ray Lennox of the Edinburgh P.D., on leave for mental, finds himself in the underbelly of American party culture. A macabre and unorthodox thriller by the author of Trainspotting.

episodes.title: Truth on the Ground in a Time of War: A Conversation Between Foreign Correspondents
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Two pre-eminent war correspondents offer a visceral understanding of America's overseas involvement-from the rise of the Taliban in Afghanistan to the heat of the battle in Iraq, from Marine battalions in Ramadi to ordinary Iraqis whose voices have remained eerily silent.

episodes.title: Angler: The Cheney Vice Presidency
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative reporter parts the curtains of secrecy to show how and why Dick Cheney operated and reflects on the legacy Cheney and the Bush administration as a whole will leave as they exit office.

episodes.title: Left in Dark Times: A Stand Against the New Barbarism
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: One of the world's leading intellectuals revisits his political roots, scrutinizes the totalitarianisms of the past, as well as those on the horizon, and argues powerfully for a new political and moral vision for our times.

episodes.title: Forgotten Histories: Two Novelists in Conversation
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Two Los Angeles-based novelists explore the rise and fall of human lives in their brilliant fictions.

episodes.title: The Hemingses of Monticello: An American Family
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A historian and legal scholar tells the compelling saga of the Hemings family, whose close blood ties to our third president have been systemically expunged from American history until very recently.

episodes.title: Give Me Liberty: A Handbook for American Revolutionaries
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A call to arms to every voter to remember what it means to live in a free democracy, and a reminder that it's possible for ordinary people to achieve extraordinary things-to get inspired and make a difference on their own.

episodes.title: Unintended Consequences: How the Iraq War Hurt America and Helped Its Enemies
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A leading authority on Iraq-and architect of the partition plan endorsed by both Democratic and Republican presidential candidates and many members of Congress-reports on the real consequences of the U.S. invasion.

episodes.title: The Photographer and His City
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The photographer whose photographs serve as visual records for this city's dramatic evolution discusses his life and creative process. Presented in conjunction with the exhibition Julius Shulman's Los Angeles, at the Central Library's Getty Gallery October 6, 2007-January 20, 2008

episodes.title: Ghost Train to the Eastern Star: 28,000 Miles in Search of the Railway Bazaar
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The writer who virtually invented the modern travel narrative returns-30 years later-to the changed landscape of Eastern Europe, Central Asia, India, China, Japan, and Siberia.

episodes.title: The Zookeeper's Wife
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The true story of the keepers of the Warsaw Zoo, who, with extraordinary courage, compassion, and calm under pressure, managed to save hundreds of people from Nazi hands.

episodes.title: The China Lover
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In his enthralling new novel, Buruma- an expert on modern Asia-uses the life of the starlet Yoshiko Yamaguchi as a lens through which to understand the contradictions and complexities of modern Japanese history.

episodes.title: Home: A Novel
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author returns to the locale of her novel Gilead in a moving and healing book about love, death, faith, families, and the passing of the generations.

episodes.title: Tried by War: Abraham Lincoln as Commander in Chief
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A Pulitzer Prize-winning historian (Battle Cry of Freedom) offers a revelatory portrait of leadership during the greatest crisis our nation has ever endured.

episodes.title: Is Reality Overrated?
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Two fiction writers discuss what's real, what's not, and whether or not it really matters.

episodes.title: Writing the World
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Discussing Hebrew, Polish, and Irish writers, four of the world's best known poets examine how local politics, national realities, and cultural traditions affect great literary traditions.

episodes.title: Building Experiences
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Considered one of the top 100 influential people in Southern California (Los Angels Times), Tim Leiweke is a visionary leader at the forefront of change in downtown Los Angeles, creating a dining and entertainment district with Staples Center and LA Live.  The collection of companies owned or operated by AEG are considered to be one of the world's leading presenters of sports and entertainment programming.

episodes.title: ALOUD Science Series: On Seeing and Being - Seeing the Divine
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: How, in this age of scientific rationalism, can we begin to understand religious visions and mystical experiences--now being reported by a growing number of people on the nightly news, across the internet, and by word-of-mouth? Dr. Lisa Bitel and Dr. Michael A. Arbib discuss visions from the Middle Ages to today, especially the tensions between cultural, spiritual, and neurological explanations for extraordinary sights, and consider new ways to understand these mysterious phenomena.Made possible by a generous contribution from K&L Gates

episodes.title: Alphabet Juice
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: America's funnyman celebrates the electricity, the juju, the breeding, the sonic and kinetic energies of letters and their combinations, reminding us that "every time you use disinterested to mean uninterested, an angel dies."

episodes.title: An Evening with Toni Morrison
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In 1993, the Nobel committee lauded Toni Morrison \"who, in novels characterized by visionary force and poetic import, gives life to an essential aspect of American reality.\" Come celebrate this magnificent author and her new novel, A Mercy.

episodes.title: Philanthrocapitalism
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: After building two Fortune 500 companies from the ground up, Eli Broad is devoting his full time and attention to philanthropy that uses entrepreneurship to advance the public good in education, science and the arts.  In his book, Philanthrocapitalism, Matthew Bishop and co-author Michael Green examine how social investors, such as Broad, are using business acumen to reshape the way charitable giving is taking place.

episodes.title: Poetry Reading and Panel Discussion Part I
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Three distinctive voices in contemporary American poetry read their work and engage in an informal group discussion on their craft.

episodes.title: Poetry Reading and Panel Discussion Part II
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Three distinctive voices in contemporary American poetry read their work and engage in an informal group discussion on their craft.

episodes.title: An Evening of Spoken Word and Cello
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Selected readings from Marisela Norte's debut collection of poetry, Peeping Tom Tom Girl, performed by long time friends and collaborators Norte y Gaitan.

episodes.title: Creative Capitalism: A Conversation with Bill Gates, Warren Buffett, and Other Economic Leaders
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Meet Michael Kinsley...TIME magazine columnist, and noted journalist who discussed his just-released book, Creative Capitalism at the ALOUD Business Forum in December. Nothing short of a revolution in thinking, Creative Capitalism is a collection of interviews and essays with Bill Gates, Warren Buffett and other key financial figures discussing the need to reinvent capitalism to benefit the world's poorest citizens. The book is intended to fuel debate, raise questions and inspire action. Kinsley was for many years the editor of The New Republic, host of CNN's Crossfire and founded Slate, the nation's first online magazine. He also served as the editorial page editor for The Los Angeles Times.

episodes.title: The Magician's Book: A Skeptic's Adventures in Narnia
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Miller, book critic and co-founder of salon.com, fell in love with the Narnia books as a child. In this intellectual adventure story, she returns to Lewis' classic fantasies to see what mysteries Narnia still holds for adult eyes.

episodes.title: Out of Exile: The Abducted and Displaced People of Sudan
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Decades of conflicts and persecution have driven millions from their homes in all parts of the northeast African country of Sudan. Many thousands more have been enslaved as human spoils of war. Writers and surprise guests read alongside Sudanese refugees who recount their lives before their displacement, the reasons for their flight, and their hopes of someday returning home.

episodes.title: The Art Instinct: Beauty, Pleasure, and Human Evolution
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Combining two fascinating and contentious disciplines -- art and evolutionary science -- a philosopher, professor and founder/editor of the popular Arts & Letter Daily, argues that human tastes in art are shaped by Darwinian selection.

episodes.title: Things I've Been Silent About: A Memoir in Moments
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The author of Reading Lolita in Tehran uses her life to transform the way we see the world and to \"remind us of why we read in the first place.\"

episodes.title: Gentrification, Neo-Feudalism, and the Colonists on Your Block: The Real Costs of a Latte
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library

episodes.title: EMBERS: A Jazz Opera in Poems
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary:
A female boxer, a madwoman stuck in Purgatory, and an irreverent angel meet across space and time to explore redemption and forgiveness in this concert reading of a work-in-progress adapted from Wolverton's novel-in-poems. Cherry plays keyboards and conducts a jazz quartet to accompany the actors who will bring to life the poetry and song.

Performed by: D'Lo, Marisol de Jesus, O-Lan Jones, Phil Meyer, Cesili Williams
and David Ornette Cherry with Organic Roots: Justo Almario, reeds; Ollie Elder Jr., bass; Don Littleton, drums, percussion.

episodes.title: Thinking About Earthquakes: A Panel Discussion
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: It's been 15 years since the 1994 quake. Is L.A. more prepared for the next one? Are WE? A panel of experts air their views: Mariana Amatullo, director, The L.A. Earthquake: Get Ready project at Art Center College of Design; Michael Dear, Professor of Geography and Urban Planning at USC; Lucy Jones, Caltech and USGS seismologist; Dennis Mileti, Director of the University of Colorado Natural Hazards Center; David Ulin, author, The Myth of Solid Ground: Earthquakes, Prediction and the Fault Line Between Reason and Faith.

episodes.title: How to Live: A Search for Wisdom From Old People (While They Are Still on This Earth)
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In his newest book, the Thurber-prize winning author interviews elder celebrities (among them Norman Mailer and LSD pioneer Ram Dass), reads deathbed confessions, Lao Tzu, William Burroughs' diaries, and considers the latest medical research on the brain as part of his quest to glean wisdom from the old (and wise) among us.

episodes.title: Wallace Stegner & the Shaping of Environmental Consciousness in the West
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A distinguished panel explores the legacy of one of the West's most influential writers, who fought for protection of the region's delicate environment as well as recognition of a Western regional base and influenced generations of environmental writers.

episodes.title: The Element: A New View of Human Capacity
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary:
The author of Out of Our Minds: Learning to Be Creative overcame polio to become one of the world's leaders in the development of creativity in business, education and human resources. Hear him hold forth on the
potential and capacity of truly \"human\" resources.

episodes.title: The Third Chapter: Passion, Risk and Adventure in the Twenty-Five Years After 50
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A renowned sociologist challenges the still-prevailing and anachronistic images of aging, tracing the ways in which wisdom, experience, and new learning inspire individual growth and cultural transformation.

episodes.title: The Pluto Files: The Rise and Fall of America's Favorite Planet
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The bestselling author and director of the world-famous Hayden Planetarium chronicles America's irrational love affair with Pluto, man's best celestial friend

episodes.title: Born to be Good: The Science of a Meaningful Life
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Why have we evolved positive emotions like gratitude, amusement, awe and compassion? Keltner, professor of psychology at UC Berkeley, offers a profound study of how emotion is the key to living the good life.

episodes.title: How We Decide
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The author of Proust Was a Neuroscientist and creator of the Frontal Cortex blog draws on cutting-edge research and the real-world experience of a wide range of \"deciders\" to arm us with the tools we need to think harder (and smarter) about how we think.

episodes.title: Sailing Home: Using the Wisdom of Homer's Odyssey
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Fischer, a poet and well-known Zen teacher, deftly incorporates Buddhist, Judaic, and Christian thought-as well as his own unique understanding of life-into this reinterpretation of Homer's ancient story.

episodes.title: Honeymoon in Tehran: Two Years of Love and Danger in Iran
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A longtime Middle East correspondent for Time Magazine-now living in Tehran-- offers a stunning and unforgettable window into the maelstrom of Iranian life and gives voice to the Iranian psyche.

episodes.title: When Markets Collide: Investment Strategies in the Age of Global Economic Change
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Global investment guru El-Erian is published widely on international economics and financial topics, has served as Managing Director of Salomon Smith Barney/Citigroup in London and has enjoyed a 15-year career at the International Monetary Fund.  He previously served as President and CEO of Harvard Management Company and as a member of the faculty of Harvard Business School.

episodes.title: Between Fountainheads
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: New Yorker veteran Weschler discusses what it has been like, the past several decades, to be serving as Boswell simultaneously to two seemingly diametrically opposite giants of the contemporary art scene, Robert Irwin and David Hockney.

episodes.title: The Domestic Drama: Novel Form or Formula?
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: American novelists are preoccupied with the tale of our (mostly dysfunctional) families. Unfortunately, contrary to Tolstoy's famous assertion, a lot of these unhappy families are starting to seem exactly alike.  Two acclaimed novelists discuss ways to tell a true, new, enduring story of our most prized institution.

episodes.title: Fresh Approaches to Branding and Marketing
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Resnick, who is one of Working Woman's Top 50 U.S. Women Business Owners began her career at the age of 19, when she founded a full-service advertising agency. She is behind the marketing success of brands such as POM Wonderful, Fiji Water and Teleflora.  She and her husband Stewart also own Paramount Farms and Paramount Citrus Companies, making them the largest farmers of tree crops in the U.S.

episodes.title: An Insomniac's Slant on Sleep
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Deftly weaving memoir and wide-ranging scientific investigation, a life-long insomniac guides us through the hidden terrain of a devastating and little understood condition.

episodes.title: The Eco-Barons: The Dreamers, Schemers, and Millionaires Who Are Saving Our Planet
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A Pulitzer Prize-winning author reveals the inspiring and largely untold stories of the country's foremost environmental conservationists, activists, and visionaries.

episodes.title: Green to the Street: The Future of Pershing Square
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Is Pershing Square a study in failed urban design? What would it take to bring it back? Could we take lessons from New York City's beloved Bryant Park? Join us for a discussion on the future of what was once one of the most vibrant and elegant public spaces in downtown Los Angeles.

episodes.title: Cutting for Stone: A Novel
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A bestselling nonfiction author and renowned physician makes the leap to fiction with this epic tale that spans three continents and five decades, from a convent in India to a cargo ship bound for Yemen; from an operating room in Ethiopia to a hospital in the Bronx.

episodes.title: Tao Te Ching: An Illustrated Journey
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A renowned scholar and translator offers a unique adaptation of the greatest passages from two ancient successors to Lao-tzu, illuminated by his own poetic commentary.

episodes.title: Cali Cali -- Three Lives from LA
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Three emerging women writers discuss using nontraditional forms for an unconventional city, writing a polyvocal landscape for a polyvocal world, publishing with an independent press, and why women write LA better than anybody.

episodes.title: Defusing Armageddon: Inside NEST, America's Secret Nuclear Bomb Squad
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Relying on recently declassified documents, Richelson--Senior Fellow with the National Security Archive--reveals how NEST operated during the Cold War, how the agency has evolved, and its current efforts to reduce the chance of a nuclear device decimating an American city.

episodes.title: A Visionary Look at the Evolution and Future of India
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Nilekani, Co-Chairman of Infosys, was named one of the 100 most influential people in the world by Time Magazine in 2006 and Forbes Businessman of the Year in 2007. In his new book Imagining India, he discusses the future of the subcontinent and its role as a global citizen and emerging economic giant.

episodes.title: Leaving India: My Family's Journey from Five Villages to Five Continents
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In this groundbreaking work, Hajratwala mixes history, memoir, and reportage to explore the questions facing not only her own Indian family but that of every immigrant: Where did we come from? Why did we leave? What did we give up and gain in the process?

episodes.title: MYhistoricLA: Preserving Los Angeles
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: SurveyLA marks a coming-of-age for LA's historic preservation movement.  Join amateur historians and LA aficionados for the public kick off of SurveyLA, share your knowledge of LA's hidden gems, view a screening of the SurveyLA video, and attend a lively panel discussion with city officials, preservationists, community organizers and developers regarding this historic survey.

episodes.title: West of the West: Dreamers, Believers, Builders & Killers in the Golden State
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Arax, a native son, spent four years traveling the breadth of the Golden State to explore its singular place in the world. From the marijuana growing capital of the U.S. to the town that inspired The Grapes of Wrath, Arax offers a stunning panorama of California in a new century.

episodes.title: Poetry Reading
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Fairchild, winner of the Kingsley Tufts Award, and Paschen, winner of the Nicholas Roerich Prize, read poems that celebrate how the humble -- the work of a machine shop, the duties of a home -- is exalted by attention and care, just as their poems are distinguished by thoughtfulness, gratitude, and a deep concern for the well-made phrase.

episodes.title: The Means of Reproduction: Sex, Power, and the Future of the World
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: An award-winning investigative reporter exposes the global war on women's reproductive rights and its disastrous and unreported consequences for the future of global development.

episodes.title: Mark Murphy & David Sefton: Two LA Impresarios
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Nigerian music, Mexican farce, John Updike, Lou Reed. Polish puppeteers, Belgian Butoh, Irish bards? what goes into the making of a season of groundbreaking performing arts at REDCAT and UCLA Live?

episodes.title: The Challenge for Africa
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Wangari Muta Maathai is the founder of the Green Belt Movement, which, through networks of rural women, has planted over 30 million trees across Kenya since 1977. In 2002, she was elected to Kenya's Parliament in the first free elections in a generation, and in 2003 was appointed Assistant Minister for Environment, Natural Resources, and Wildlife. The Nobel Peace Prize laureate of 2004, she is the author of Unbowed: A Memoir, and speaks to organizations around the world.  Her newest book, The Challenge for Africa addresses the intricacies of African issues, such as the lack of technological developments, the absence of fair international trade, population pressures and enduring hunger, and the dearth of genuine political and economic leadership.  Maathai stresses the need for Africans to invent and implement their own solutions, rather than relying on foreign aid and Western visions of change, and calls for a revolution in leadership on both a political and individual level.

episodes.title: A Lucky Child
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Buergenthal, currently the American judge at the International Court of Justice in The Hague, arrived at Auschwitz at age ten, and was soon separated from his mother and then his father. In this inspiring memoir, he reminds us of the resilience of the human spirit.

episodes.title: Linda Gregerson, Paul Muldoon, and Robert Pinsky: Three Kingley Tufts Prize Judged Read from Their Own Poetry
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Three members of the final judging panel for the Kingsley and Kate Tufts Poetry Awards, read from their own prize-winning work.

episodes.title: The Novel!  Why There's Nothing Quite Like It
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Smiley, the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist and author of Thirteen Ways of Looking at the Novel, talks about how novels work and why we like them.

episodes.title: The Post-Human Dada Guide: Tzara and Lenin Play Chess
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Magically blending sarcasm and gravity, America's favorite surrealist poet and NPR commentator offers an impractical handbook for practical living in our posthuman world.

episodes.title: Newer Poets XIV
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Join us for this exuberant annual reading with emerging Los Angeles-area poets.

episodes.title: How to Win a Cosmic War: God, Globalization & the End of the War on Terror
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Surveying the global scene, a preeminent scholar of religion launches a revolution in the way we understand-and confront-radical Islam.

episodes.title: Manatee/Humanity: Poetry Performance
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Waldman-- a \"Cat 4 hurricane of unchained imagination, curiosity, and invention, political rage and erotic elation.\"-draws on animal lore, animal encounters, dreams, evolutionary biology, neuroscience, and Buddhist ritual in her new investigative hybrid-poem exploring the nuances of inter-species communication and compassion

episodes.title: Hallelujah Junction: Composing an American Life
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: One of America's most performed and admired composers, Adams (Nixon in China, Doctor Atomic) helped shape the landscape of contemporary classical music.  His new memoir reveals the inner workings of his creative process and illuminates the recent history of music-making.

episodes.title: Losing Mum and Pup
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In this tragicomic true story of the year in which both of his parents died, the award-winning author and humorist captures the heartbreaking and disorienting feeling of becoming a 55-year-old orphan.

episodes.title: Sag Harbor: A Novel
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The historically African- American enclave of Sag Harbor, on the east end of Long Island, is the setting for the wonderfully funny, supremely original novel by the MacArthur award-winning author of The Intuitionist.

episodes.title: An Afternoon with Tom Brokaw
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Join us for an illuminating conversation with Tom Brokaw, veteran news anchor, author and 2009 recipient of the Los Angeles Public Library Literary Award.

episodes.title: Blogging the Narco-Wars: A Panel Discussion
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Violence spills north of the border after the bloodiest year in the war to control drug smuggling through Tijuana.  Join journalists from San Diego and Tijuana and a long-time watchdog of border violence to discuss the difficulties faced and methods used by reporters doing their jobs in Tijuana.

episodes.title: Notes on Sontag
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A renowned essayist considers the achievements and limitations of his tantalizing, daunting subject.

episodes.title: Smogtown: The Lung-Burning History of Pollution in Los Angeles
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: How did smog help mold the modern-day culture of Los Angeles? Join this discussion about pollution, progress and the epic struggle against airborne poisons.

episodes.title: Mirrors: Stories of Almost Everyone
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In this history of human adventure, one of Latin America's most distinguished writers illuminates movements of ideas and society across centuries by recalling the lives of artists, writers, gods and visionaries-- from the Garden of Eden to 21st-century New York.

episodes.title: Lost in the Meritocracy: The Undereducation of an Overachiever
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A peerless interpreter of American life recounts his own long strange trip from rural Minnesota to the ivy-covered walls of Princeton-- a fascinating examination of the perils of an education that prizes the accumulation of points over the enrichment of the mind.

episodes.title: Dreamers in Dream City: A Journey Through Portraits
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Photographer/author Harry Brant Chandler and historian Kevin Starr explore the fascinating lives of inspirational Southern Californians, the subjects of Chandler's unique portraits.

episodes.title: The Political Mind: A Cognitive Scientist's Guide to Your Brain and Its Politics
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: One of the world's best-known cognitive scientists explains why understanding language is critical in politics and why Reason is not as reasonable as we thought.

episodes.title: Destiny Disrupted: A History of the World Through Islamic Eyes
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Ansary, native of Afghanistan and astute cultural interpreter, tells the rich story of world history as the Islamic world sees it, from the time of Mohammed to the fall of the Ottoman Empire and beyond.

episodes.title: The Dark Side: The Inside Story of How the War on Terror Turned into a War on American Ideals
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A New Yorker reporter's definitive account of how decisions made behind closed doors in Washington spiraled out around the world, often with unintended consequences.

episodes.title: A Bright and Guilty Place: Murder, Corruption, and L.A.'s Scandalous Coming of Age
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Tabloid crimes, the Roaring 20's, and the onset of the Depression form the backdrop of Rayner's captivating tale of how the City of Angels lost its soul.

episodes.title: Riverbig: A Novel
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: \"Crimes litter the floor of California's great Central Valley like fallen plums . . . Old ties of blood, friendship, and memory are harshly tested . . . but hope takes root in the valley's generous yet unforgiving soil.\" (D.J. Waldie)

episodes.title: Erased
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Abandonment, life, death (and, oddly, Cleveland) are explored in the hilarious second installment of Jim Krusoe's trilogy of novels about resurrection.

episodes.title: Towers of Gold: How One Jewish Immigrant Named Isaias Hellman Created California
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: An award-winning journalist chronicles the life of her great-great grandfather, a brilliant gold-rush era entrepreneur and financier, who rose from store clerk to the upper echelons of society, founded L.A.'s first bank, resurrected the financially troubled Los Angeles Times, and helped establish U.S.C.

episodes.title: The Contemporary City: Urbanism in Flux
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary:
What alternative avenues for urbanism can be developed as existing models have been undermined by the current economic crisis?  How will issues of planning, infrastructure, and the public realm shape architecture and design in the coming generation?

Presented in conjunction with the exhibition \"Richard Neutra, Architect: Sketches and Drawings in the Getty Gallery\"

episodes.title: Farm City: The Education of an Urban Farmer
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Urban and rural collide in this wry, inspiring memoir of a woman who turned a vacant lot in downtown Oakland into a thriving farm.

episodes.title: Visions in the Desert: Searching for Home in the West
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary:
An evening of stories and songs by Rubén Martinez, with Joe Garcia and featuring John Schayer and Ruben Gonzalez

High end art colonies materialize on dusty plains. Mexican migrant corridors transect Native lands. Writer Martinez, accompanied by his longtime musical partner, explores some of the oldest American symbols and the newest motley cast of characters to confront them.

episodes.title: Why Design Matters
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary:
How do notions of social responsibility and sustainability, in terms of design, impact the response to the growing density of Los Angeles and beyond?

Presented in conjunction with the exhibition \"Richard Neutra, Architect: Sketches and Drawings in the Getty Gallery\"

episodes.title: Unscientific America: How Scientific Illiteracy Threatens Our Future
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Why, when many of the problems of the twenty-first century require scientific solutions, are Americans paying less and less attention to scientists? How might we reverse this alarming trend and integrate science into our national discourse--before it's too late?

episodes.title: A Paradise Built in Hell: The Extraordinary Communities that Arise in Disaster
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: Can the social connectedness that arises in the aftermath of a disaster-whether natural or manmade-lead us to a new vision of society?

episodes.title: A Gate at the Stairs
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In her long-awaited new novel, set after the events of September 2001, Moore brings us up against the heart of racism, the shock of war, and the carelessness perpetrated against others in the name of love.

episodes.title: The Anthologist
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In re-imagining the lives and loves of history's great poets, Baker creates a seductive meditation on poetry and artistic expression.

episodes.title: The Boat
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In his first book, Le writes stunningly inventive stories that take us from the slums of Columbia to the streets of Tehran; from a tiny fishing village in Australia to a foundering vessel in the South China Sea.

episodes.title: No Impact Man: The Adventures of a Guilty Liberal Who Attempts to Save the Planet and the Discoveries He Makes about Himself and our Way of Life in the Process
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: No toilet paper! No plastic containers! No new clothes! No eating out! Beavan discusses-and screens film clips about-- his family's yearlong experiment to live a zero waste lifestyle in New York City.

episodes.title: Justice: What's the Right Thing to Do?
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary:
Sandel--whose Justice course is one of the most popular and influential at Harvard-- hallenges us to think our way through the hard moral challenges we confront as citizens. 

Co-presented by the Council of the Library Foundation and City National Bank

episodes.title: An Evening with Garrison Keillor
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The host and writer of \"A Prairie Home Companion\" knows how to spin a yarn. Join us for an evening of inspired storytelling, as Keillor converts the \"base metal of small town tedium to the gold of comedy.\" (NYTimes)

episodes.title: Logicomix: An Epic Search for Truth
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A renowned professor of computer science recounts the spiritual odyssey of philosopher Bertrand Russell in a historical graphic novel that explicates some of the biggest ideas of mathematics and modern philosophy.

episodes.title: Brother West: Living and Loving Out Loud
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: In this intimate exploration, one of America's most gifted and provocative public intellectuals peels back the layers of a remarkable life.

episodes.title: Manhood for Amateurs: The Pleasures and Regrets of a Husband, Father, and Son
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: A shy manifesto and an impractical handbook by one of America's finest writers.

episodes.title: Strength in What Remains: A Journey of Remembrance and Forgetting
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author of Mountains Beyond Mountains tells the inspiring tale of Deogratias (Deo), a young medical student from the mountains of Burundi, who narrowly survived civil war and genocide before seeking a new life in America.

episodes.title: The Holocaust by Bullets
episodes.author: Los Angeles Public Library
episodes.summary:
Desbois, a French Catholic priest, has devoted his life to confronting anti-Semitism and furthering Catholic-Jewish understanding.
